pull_requests.title: BIP-348 (OP_CHECKSIGFROMSTACK) (regtest only)
pull_requests.body:
This implements [BIP-348 (`OP_CHECKSIGFROMSTACK`)](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0348.md), but only specifies a regtest deployment. There is no effective policy change, since the SCRIPT_VERIFY_* flags (as used) result in the same OP_SUCCESS-like behavior.

This change can be composed with other opcode specifications (e.g. CTV, see #31989) and bundled into the same deployment (yet to be specified).

I encourage more general, conceptual discussion to happen on [Delving Bitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/) and not on this pull request.

Some related discussion on Delving Bitcoin here:
- https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/ctv-csfs-can-we-reach-consensus-on-a-first-step-towards-covenants/

See also:
- https://bitcoinops.org/en/topics/op_checksigfromstack/

Concept ACK
Concept ACK

cr ACK [cb0c9f6](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32247/commits/cb0c9f6389abc1d24b4fb8b80eaaa539acd81f92)

This matches the BIP's semantics, and the implementation is reasonable. Minor nits above to reduce possibility of behavior changes for other users of Schnorr APIs.

I spent a bit of time writing tests (reading directly from the BIP) for feature_taproot.py: https://github.com/instagibbs/bitcoin/tree/2025-04-bip348_tests

This should hopefully give some nice coverage of border conditions, including sigops budget and maybe inspired people to add more if they want to contribute in a positive way.

https://github.com/instagibbs/bitcoin/tree/2025-03-bip348-inq-28 this was an alternative implementation of the core logic, but I think it matches here
Thanks @instagibbs; I've compressed your test changes into a single commit and added that here.

pull_requests.title: doc: Updates how to reproduce fuzz CI failure locally
pull_requests.body: The current version of the doc does not explain how to reproduce a recent fuzzing CI failure (not yet part of the corpora). Add instructions on how to manually create a crash file based on a report.

If your review is incorrectly listed, please react with üëé to this comment and the bot will ignore it on the next update.

> The current version of the doc does not accurately explain how to reproduce a fuzzing CI failure. It seems to imply that you have access to the crash file on CI, and does not describe how to create the file locally and what data to encode.

I think the current docs are correct. Generally, the CI iterates over a fixed set of files and those are in a separate repo. The docs apply here.

Only in the rare case, where:

* No fixed set of files has been added yet
* The fuzz target can trigger a crash and reach it in less than 60 seconds from an empty set of files

I'd say it is pretty rare, but if you want to add docs for it, that is fine. Though, I am not sure about removing the existing and correct docs.

I may have missed the point of the section. However, I think there is a missing case in which you are trying to reproduce a fuzzing crash reported by CI that was not part of the corpus, which should be analogous to reproducing a crash case reported by someone else.

I'll undo the changes and add that as an extra section if that makes sense.

Also, the base64 stuff isn't printed for large files. For example https://cirrus-ci.com/task/4877497478676480?logs=ci#L3895:

issues.title: [Mac] Blockchain corrupts on every quit, shows terrible dialog
issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Current behaviour

1. I'm loading blockchain, and when quitting Mac app it corrupts every time.
2. It shows dialog where if I press highlighted button whole blockchain is deleted and it starts downloading again.

### Expected behaviour

1. It does not corrupt ever.
2. It shows options to fix it without removing. And remove options is not highlighted but is with red color and additional dialog to confiirm, telling that it would remove blockchain.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Start downloading.
2. Quit the app.

### Relevant log output

<log already overwritten>

### How did you obtain Bitcoin Core

Pre-built binaries

### What version of Bitcoin Core are you using?

28.1

### Operating system and version

MacOS 15.3.2 (24D81)

### Machine specifications

MacOS, MacBook M1, external HD ExFAT (Disk Utility First Aid shows everything is OK), good WIFI
